texts.definition: The act of placing game elements when their spatial relation to other such game elements affects gameplay.
markups: <style="Definition">The act of placing game elements when their spatial relation to other such game elements affects gameplay.</style>

Some games use the spatial relations between game elements to represent aspects of game worlds or relations in abstract structures. <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> exists in these games when the elements and relations are not fixed but created through placing them, and it is likely that the resulting relations differ between game instances.
Note: While the pattern name suggests only the laying of Tiles, it is also applicable to Cards, Tokens, and Units.

As the name suggests, <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> primarily occurs in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tile-Based%20Games">Tile-Based Games</link></style>. For example, players' turns in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style> consist of drawing and laying a tile in connection to those already in play and then optionally placing a token. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Samurai">Samurai</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neuroshima%20Hex">Neuroshima Hex</link></style> have similar gameplay structures to depict struggles over land areas. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Small%20World">Small World</link></style> lets players place a number of units (and sometimes other tokens) as part of their turn. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Acquire">Acquire</link></style> using <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> to abstractly represent competitions between hotel chains and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Android">Android</link></style> uses played tiles to unveil a conspiracy; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati">Illuminati</link></style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Game</link></style> where its is instead used to abstractly represent power structures. Tiles are placed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Drakborgen">Drakborgen</link></style> gradually as the players' explore the gameplay area. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms%20(board%20game)">Kingdoms</link></style> is a math-oriented <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> game with a fantasy theme.

Weaker examples of <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> exist in games where the <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> is done before gameplay begins. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> is commonly played this way in order to ensure that the resources provided on its hexagonal tiles are randomized. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rogue">Rogue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Angband">Angband</link></style>, early <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> that used ASCII-based graphics, randomizes the layout of levels for each game session.

<style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> is nearly always a form of <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, and the primary design choice if one wishes to have it present in a game design is to decide if <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can sometimes also be used (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Small%20World">Small World</link></style>) when they are placed onto <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> rather than moved around on them, and in this case does not necessarily need to be seen as <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> may be used either before game play begins as part of the setup phase of the game or during gameplay as part of the actions players perform.  While <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> is typically used in both cases, in the later case <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> are also common and sometimes combined with variants of <style="Link"><link="hands">Hands</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> a concrete way to construct <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or abstract structures whose relations are shown through spatial positioning. When laid <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, etc.) can be moved, this allows for <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> during gameplay but this pattern is in one sense always supported by the game since the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> can change between game instances. While <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> can allow <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> goals, <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> can more directly link to this if players place <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> as they do the actual exploration (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Drakborgen">Drakborgen</link></style>). <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> done before gameplay occurs can create <style="Link"><link="fog-war">Fog of War</link></style> simply by placing <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> upside down. When players control the placement of the game elements that are used for the <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> to makes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Constructed%20Worlds">Player-Constructed Worlds</link></style> possible.

Regardless if players are placing the tiles or <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> is used, the variation this causes makes it likely that games with <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> have <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>. This, or the <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> that <style="CurrentLink">Tile-Laying</style> can provide, supports <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>.
